thread.title: Cleveland Browns QB Josh McCown hopes to rewrite history
thread.title_full: Cleveland Browns QB Josh McCown hopes to rewrite history

title: Cleveland Browns QB Josh McCown hopes to rewrite history
text:
Cleveland Browns QB Josh McCown hopes to rewrite history Cleveland Browns quarterback Josh McCown hopes to rewrite his own personal history. Post to Facebook Cleveland Browns QB Josh McCown hopes to rewrite history Cleveland Browns quarterback Josh McCown hopes to rewrite his own personal history.  //on.wkyc.com/1LvMNb1   Join the Conversation To   Cleveland Browns QB Josh McCown hopes to rewrite history Matthew Florjancic, WKYC 11:54 a.m. EDT October 15, 2015 Cleveland Browns quarterback Josh McCown hopes to rewrite his own personal history. Cleveland Browns quarterback Josh McCown hopes to rewrite his own personal history. (Photo: Tommy Gilligan-USA TODAY Sports) 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
BEREA, Ohio -- Cleveland Browns quarterback Josh McCown broke a pair of franchise records in last Sunday's 33-30 win over the Baltimore Ravens at M&T Bank Stadium, and he is looking to rewrite a little more history against the Denver Broncos this weekend. 
After being named the AFC Offensive Player of the Week following his 457-yard, three-touchdown (two passing, one rushing) performance against the Ravens, McCown reflected on the last time he was named the conference player of the week when he was with the Chicago Bears. 
"The last time I got it, I got benched, so I've got my fingers crossed right now," McCown said with a laugh after Wednesday's practice. "It's just a reflection of the guys and what we're doing, and I just happen to be in front of it. 
"But that's everybody. That's really how I feel about that. That's the front five, that's the backs, that's the receivers, that's the tights, that's all of us together, and it's just a reflection of our effort and preparation. So I just happen to be the guy who's name's on it, but that's all of us." 
McCown completed 36 of his 51 throws for 457 yards and two touchdowns in the win over the Ravens. The 457 yards were a single-game franchise record, surpassing the previous mark of 444 collected by Brian Sipe against the Baltimore Colts on October 25, 1981. 
"First off, I'm happy for him," Broncos coach Gary Kubiak said of McCown. "Obviously, I think the world of him. He's been battling for years in this league, and then, to get this great opportunity and take advantage of it, that's what this league is all about. (I'm) very impressed. I have got a lot of respect for him. What he did last week going into Baltimore, I know how tough that is having been there last year, so he's doing a great job." 
McCown, the first Browns quarterback to have three straight 300-yard passing performances, has increased his passing yardage totals in each of the last three weeks, and his 1,154 combined yards between starts against the Oakland Raiders, San Diego Chargers and Ravens are the most in a three-game stretch by any quarterback in Browns history. 
But more than anything, McCown was happy to briefly celebrate the accomplishment with his teammates before the Browns got to work on the Broncos. 
"That's what's really been the coolest part," McCown said. "I guess I didn't fully understand the scope of the last time these guys beat the Ravens and all those things. I think more over the last few days, I've been able to talk with guys about that and talk with Joe (Thomas) and guys that have been around here a while and really internalize that and, absolutely, appreciate it a little bit more. Again, you do that to a point, but then, it's time to move on and that's where we're at now." 
Although McCown was quick to deflect any of the success, Pettine knows the individual statistics came as a result of his quarterback's practice habits, which he expects to continue as the Browns prepare to take on the league's top-ranked defense. 
"He is very prepared," Pettine said. "He understands when a play gets called, the play from A to Z. He understands it well, the formation, who needs to be where, the timing of any particular motion, the spacing of the wide receivers and then, what the read is. If the route is built to where we have a blitz-beater on one side and a zone-beater on the other, he can recognize a defense. 
"He is decisive. The throws that he has made for the most part have been extremely accurate. If you are going to have a quarterback play that well, you have to be doing something good around him. For the most part, we protected well on that many pass attempts. 
"I know we gave up some hits and some sacks, but I think overall, the protection was there certainly when we needed it. We ran good routes. The receivers were where they were supposed to be and caught the football and we broke tackles and got some positive yards. I just think he has a great understanding and a great command of what we are doing. When you are accurate and on time on top of that, you are going to get those types of results." 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.wkyc.com/1LvMNb1 TOP VIDEOS
